XTAL

Crystal Oscillator Topology

Crystal Oscillator (38.4 MHz) Topology Diagram
Crystal Oscillator Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Length matching between XTAL_IN and XTAL_OUTTotal length mismatch: 1.27 mm.
GND shieldingGND shielding to adjacent signals (especially high speed IO) is recommended.
Main route (MR)Main route (MR) is recommended to be limited to SL/ DSL to limit coupling and impact from EMI/ RFI sources.
Reference planeContinuous GND only; do not reference to power planes. If routed as stripline or dual stripline, both top and bottom reference/ adjacent planes MUST be solid continuous ground. Avoid routing directly parallel (under/ over/shadow) to high current power planes. If unavoidable route signal orthogonal to power plane.
External capacitor valueExternal capacitors C1 and C2 must be matched (C1 = C2).Capacitor values should be tuned accordingly with respect to load capacitance for crystal. If the crystal load capacitance reduces (per component datasheet information), then C1/C2 should be reduced accordingly as well. Due to vendor variation in crystal characteristic, layout variation and PCB trace, calculation is recommended to determine the C1/C2 value.
Rs resistorsResistors Rs1 and Rs2 are required for potential stuffing options for RFI/ EMI purposes.
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia PlacementNotes
Tx2Total Channelrecommended to minimize number of vias

Segment Lengths

Crystal Oscillator Topology Segment Lengths Routing Guidelines
SegmentTline TypeMax Length Segment (mm)
BOMS, DSL12.7
MRDSL

Max Length Total (mm): 25.4

Max Length Total Note: Recommended 0201 component sizes

EIO Flexi-PDG for I2C, SMBus/SMLink

Description: EIO Flexi-PDG for I2C, SMBus/SMLink.

VDD2PWRGOOD

VDD2PWRGOOD Topology

VDD2PWRGOOD Topology Diagram
VDD2PWRGOOD Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Routing restrictionRoute the signal far away from the noisy source/signal. Follow the small routing length as possible.
R0 (placeholder).
Signal name/ listVDD2PWRGOOD_IN, VDD2PWRGOOD_OUT

EPD_ON

EPD_ON Topology

EPD_ON Topology Diagram
EPD_ON Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Routing restrictionRoute the signal far away from the noisy source/signal. Follow the small routing length as possible. It is strongly recommended to meet routing near switching voltage regulator guidelines for SVID signals. Refer to "Switching VR Circuit Guideline" chapter in PDG for the details. (Technical White Paper Doc#: 726825)
Signal name/ listEPD_ON_OUT, EPD_ON_CPU_IN

DDR5

Description: DDR5 SODIMM

SODIMM 1DPC Type-3

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-3, 0.8mm

DDR5 SODIMM Type-3 6L Signals Topologies
DDR5 SODIMM Block Diagram
DDR5 SODIMM 1DPC Top-Pin Bottom-Pin Definition and Compensation
SODIMM 1DPC Type-3 Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupType-3 stackup with minimum of 6 layer.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Number of vias allowedMax 2 transition vias.
Ground stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP / clip files.
Max MS BO/ BI lengthRefer to RFI/ EMC guidelines for the max microstrip BO/ BI length requirement.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. DDR5: Byte Swapping is allowed within each x32 channel.
Diff pair length matchingMatch diff pair P-N within 0.2 mm at each layer.
MS BO and BI segment, PTH patternKeep DDR MS BO and BI as close as possible to reference board.
DDR to Non-DDR trace spacingMinimum 500 um.
Unused signalsDDR signals on CPU which are not applicable for DDR5 can be left unconnected (example ALERT).
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm

MD x32 Type-3 Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupType-3 stackup with minimum of 6 layers.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
GND stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP/ clip files.
Max MS BO/ BI lengthRefer to RFI/ EMC guidelines for the maximum microstrip BO/ BI length requirement.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. Byte swapping is allowed within a 16-bit channel. LPDDR5: x16 sub-channels can be swizzled within their x64 MC. When swapping channel DQ, the CA/CS signals must be swapped as well.
Unused signalsLeave unused DDR signals (PARITY, extra CA) floating (no connect). ALERT is also unused and can be left floating (no connect) at CPU side.
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm

EMC General Considerations

Ground Ring

PCB ground (GND) rings on all layers with GND PTH vias are recommended along the edge of the board. Multiple mounting holes should be used connecting the PCB GND to chassis ground. It can significantly reduce the PCB edge coupled noise.

Guidelines for PCB GND Ring and GND Stitching Vias

Multiple GND stitching vias are required on all mechanical mounting pads including for internal device modules (e.g. SSD, WiFi module) and I/O connectors (e.g. USB) throughout the platform.

Ground Ring with Ground Vias

Connector Decoupling

Place a decoupling capacitor (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) on the power pins of all internal and external connectors to reduce power noise. These connectors include HDMI, eDP, USB, Type C, FPC connectors, M.2, PCIe edge connector, etc.

Decoupling Capacitors Placement on Connector Power Pins

Crossing Splits in Reference Plane

Crossing a split in the reference plane increases emissions from signal traces. Avoid crossing plane splits by moving the traces or reshape the reference plane.

Avoid Signal Traces Routings Across Split Planes

Reference Discontinuity

Changing reference plane from GND to power plane, or from power plane A to power plane B, may significantly increase noise emission. It is recommended to have stitching capacitors (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) to bridge the two reference planes and provide current return path. The stitching capacitor must be placed as close as possible to the signal trace.

Reduce Signal Referencing Discontinuities Impact

Crystal RF Immunity

The crystal oscillator that provides the input clock to the CPU has been identified to be very sensitive to RF power from nearby radios. Radiated power from internal WWAN and WLAN antennas as well as from external WWAN/ WLAN devices placed near the platform can couple to the crystal and corrupt the clock signal causing issues such as screen flickering and system hang. Similarly the crystal used with the Thunderbolt retimer is very sensitive to RF power, and noise from nearby antennas can result in connection loss with the device plugged into the Thunderbolt port. Refer to retimer collaterals (document number: #572046) for XTAL specifications. The following RF Immunity Guidelines apply to both the 38.4 MHz crystal, RTC (real-time clock) crystal as well as the Thunderbolt/ retimer crystal.

  • Follow crystal routing guidelines very carefully. (Refer to XTAL design guidelines section).

  • Implement a ground ring surrounding crystal and related components. Refer to below figure. Do not connect external load caps to GND ring, but rather directly to GND plane on adjacent layer.

  • Use a shielded crystal component.

  • Ensure that external high speed IO ( USB3.x/2/1.x) and internal high speed IO (PCIe) traces are not routed in close proximity to the crystal components and traces (XTAL_IN/OUT).

  • Place crystal far away from antennas and potential RF power coupling paths such as unshielded/ungrounded cables. Exact distance needed depends on platform design. Platforms without board shield may have higher risk.

  • Chassis shielding and design plays a critical role in RF immunity. Refer to the EMC Mechanical Considerations section and collateral #602554.

The following RF guideline apply to RTC (real-time) crystal

  • Design a footprint for the RF capacitor on the power plane (+Vcc1p5_RTC) for RTC. The capacitance of the stuffed RF capacitor should be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power. The footprint should be as close as possible to CPU side.

RF capacitor placement recommendation for RTC crystal

XTAL Ground Ring Requirements

Adding a ground ring surrounding the crystal component, related components and routing can help reduce RF immunity risk.

Guidelines for XTAL Ground Ring Implementation and Components for RF Immunity

Memory RFI Mitigation

Memory interface and DRAM devices generate narrowband and broadband RFI noise. The noise may interfere with radio bands. The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to memory.

Memory RFI Mitigation Consideration

Design AreaWi-Fi only designsWi-Fi and WWAN/ 5G designs
Memory signals on Type-4 boardFully stripline required Fully stripline required
Memory signals main routing on Type-3 boardMain routing fully stripline requiredMain routing fully stripline required
Memory signals breakout routing on Type-3 boardDQ microstrip breakout signals <= 6.5 mm CLK, WCK, DQS, CA microstrip breakout signals <= 9 mmDQ microstrip breakout signals <= 6.5 mm CLK, WCK, DQS, CA microstrip breakout signals <= 9 mm
Memory device (SODIMM, solder down memory) shieldingRequired antenna distance needs to be considered based on system dependencyRequired antenna distance needs to be considered based on system dependency
Exposed memory power planes referenced to groundRF capacitors are recommendedRF capacitors are recommended
Exposed memory power planes referenced to memory signalsOn-board shield required and RF capacitors are requiredOn-board shield required and RF capacitors are required Additional RF capacitors for WWAN interfere frequencies may require
Memory Radio Frequency Interference Mitigation (RFIM) EnablingRecommended. Please refer to Intel White Paper # 640438Recommended. Please refer to Intel White Paper # 640438

Memory Signals and Power Plane Routing

It is recommended that DQ/ CLK/ DQS/ WCK/ CA signals are routed in inner layers, or the microstrip breakout trace length is required to be minimized as table below. An isolation ground guard ring is recommended on the surface layer between memory power plane and memory breakout signal routing.

Signal TypesTotal Microstrip Breakout Length (mm)
DQ<= 6.5
CLK, WCK, DQS, CA<= 9

* BI microstrip length should be 1.5 mm based on system dependency.

It is recommended to embed memory power planes in inner PCB layers. If embedding memory power plane is not possible, please consider the following design guide: When exposed memory power planes (VDD2/VDDQ) are referenced to solid GND, and memory data rate falls into Wi-Fi 2.4 GHz/ 5 GHz/ 6 GHz and WWAN radio bands, exposed memory power planes can radiate narrowband RFI noise at data rate frequency.

  • It is recommended to add platform RF capacitors to mitigate power plane noise (refer to exposed memory Power plane RF capacitors decoupling below).

  • It is recommended to shield exposed memory power planes or add absorber.

  • If data rate does not fall into radio bands, the platform RF capacitors guideline can be optional.

When exposed memory power planes are referenced to memory signals, exposed memory power planes can radiate both narrowband and broadband RFI noise.

  • It is required to add platform RF capacitors to mitigate power plane noise (refer to exposed memory power plane RF Capacitor placement as below).

  • It is required to shield exposed memory power planes or add absorber.

  • Highly recommend to avoid surface memory power plane reference to memory signal, instead, surface memory power planes shall be referenced to solid GND plane in adjacent layer.

RFI Suppression Guidelines on Memory Signal and Power Plane Exposure
Exposed Memory Power Plane RF Decoupling Capacitors

Memory power plane could be shared or separated based on design configuration.

RF decoupling capacitors are paired in groups.

  • 0402 12 pF and 0402 2.2 pF

  • 0201 15 pF and 0201 3.0 pF

RF decoupling capacitors pairs placement.

  • < 4 mm proximity from CPU and memory devices

  • Pair-to-pair distance < 12 mm.

  • Evenly distributed.

Memory Devices

Memory devices (ex. DRAM, SODIMM) can radiate broadband and narrowband RFI noise and may cause radio frequency interference. A combination of EMI shield and antenna placement is required to mitigate noise from memory devices.

SODIMM memory devices can cause higher RFI noise than the soldered down DRAM devices and it is highly recommended to use an EMI shield for the SODIMM memory devices.

Refer to the sections On-Board Shielding and Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature for more information.

Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature

DDRRFIM is a frequency-shiftingRFI-mitigation software feature. The DDR RFIM feature is primarily aimed at resolving narrowband RFI from memory (DDR and LPDDR technologies and both soldered-down and modules) forthe Wi-Fi in high frequency bands (5 to 7GHz). By changing theDDR data rate, using Intel dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) technology, the narrowband memory noiseat the clock harmonic frequency can be shifted out of a radio band of interest, thus mitigating RFI to the radio.The change of the DDR data rate is dynamic based on the radio channelin use.

DynamicDDR data rateselection and controlcan be done at the request of the Intel integratedWi-Fifirmware (CNVi) orat the request of Intels DTT DDR RFIM policy. In systems with CNVi installed, the feature is enabled by default. In systems with discrete Intel or 3rd party Wi-Fi, the DDR RFIM policy must be enabled in DTT. For both cases, the OEM has the option to customize the DDR RFI table (list of Wi-Fi channels affected by each DDR frequency of the system) based on the measured platform noise.

Intel also offers a semiautomatic tool to characterize the platform DDR noise and customize the DDR RFI table that is an input to RFIM. It is highly recommended to use the tool to characterize the noise from the different memory DVFS points. Please refer to white papers #640438 and #816192 for detailed information.

DLVR RFI Mitigation

The Digital Linear Voltage Regulator (DLVR) may induce RF noise on input power planes / rails that couple to radio antennas, resulting in RF interference within radio bands.

The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to DLVR.

Minimize DLVR Input Planes Exposure

It is recommended that the DLVR input power plane (VCCIA/VCC_PCORE & VCCSA ) size be minimized on surface layers while considering PI requirements. Refer to power integrity requirement for resistance and VR sense feedback recommendations.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on DLVR Input Power Planes

High-frequency decoupling capacitors on the DLVR input power plane(s) can help in DLVR noise-reduction. Since there are system-level dependencies for the RFI, in certain scenarios (like a system with aggressive antenna placement to DLVR input power plane or WWAN radio), it is recommended to have placeholders for decoupling capacitors. The following table and figures show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors and an example of layout implementation.

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for DLVR
Example of RF Cap Placement for DLVR power plane

Graphic (GFX) Power Planes RFI Design Guidelines

Graphics (GFX) may induce RF noise on power planes / rails that couple to radio antennas, resulting in RF interference within radio bands. The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to GFX power planes.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on GFX Power Planes

It is recommended to have placeholders for high-frequency decoupling capacitors on the VCCGT (GFX power plane). These decoupling capacitors may help in reducing potential GFX noise in certain scenarios such as a system with aggressive antenna placement to GFX power planes. The following table and figure show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors:

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for GFX Power Planes
Case #Location of Decoupling CapacitorGFX RF Capacitors for 2.4GHz BandComments$[internal]Cap Stuffing Option for Internal Validation
Case 1Directly underneath pair of GFX power via and GND vias (Directly from BGAs) on the plane0201 size: 6 x capacitors (Suggested value: between 22pF to 33pF)Preferred placement for RF decoupling capacitors.Capacitors are recommended to be placed directly underneath the pair of NPU / GFX power via - GND vias at bottom layer or at least within the CPUs shadow area. The value of the RF capacitor may need to be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power within Wi-Fi bands. Stuffed
Case 2 5mm from GFX power via BGA 0201 size: 6 x capacitors (Suggested value: between 22pF to 33pF) The value of the RF capacitor may need to be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power within Wi-Fi bands.Stuffed
Case 3> 5mm away from GFX power via BGA Not recommended RF capacitors are NOT effective for RFI reduction in this location of placement.Stuffed

HSIO RFI Mitigation

Exposed high speed I/O routing traces are regarded as RFI source. The RFI level depends on interface signal characteristics such as data rate, rise/ fall time and coupling between antenna and signal trace.

Minimize Exposed High Speed I/O Channel Routing

It is recommended that the routing of I/O interface in table below be embedded in inner layers and covered by solid ground. Due to routing limitations, full stripline routing may not be possible. Recommend < 38 mm microstrip routing at breakout region and < 25 mm microstrip routing at connector region to reduce EMI/ RFI risk.

InterfaceData RateMax Breakout Length (Microstrip)Max Routing Length at Connector Region (Microstrip)Cable ShieldingNote
CNVio3 (STEP)12 GbpsRefer to CNVio3 subsection (under High Speed chapter's CNVio Bus section)Refer to CNVio3 subsection (under High Speed chapter's CNVio Bus section)Not applicableKeep out distance of CNVio3' signals (microstrip) to Wi-Fi antenna > 15 mm.Refer to document #610694 for the latest Intel Wi-Fi module RFI/EMC recommendations.
DMIC Clk< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
eDP 1.48.1 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
HDMI 2.05.94 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
PCIe416 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
PCIe Refclk100 MHz< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
SPI Clk< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
Type-C USB+DP10, 20 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
Type-C USB+DP+TBT20 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB2.0480 Mbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB3.2 Gen15 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB3.2 Gen210 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax

eDP RFI Mitigation

Narrowband Spur Noise from eDP Data and TCON Clock

To prevent interference with radio bands, select the eDP data rates that ensure the fundamental frequencies and harmonics of the eDP signals do not fall into Wi-Fi radio bands. The eDP data rates 2.43 Gbps and 6.75 Gbps should be avoided to mitigate the RF noise impact on Wi-Fi radios. Other mitigation solutions such as using high-quality shielding cable for eDP and TCON connection/board or enabling spread spectrum clocking may provide effective but limited noise reduction as an alternative solution.

Mitigate eDP RF interference by preventing using data rate that falling into Wi-Fi radios
TCON clock noise falling into Wi-Fi bands

RF Interference from Embedded Display Port (eDP) Interface and TCON

In mobile designs, RF interference from eDP interface has become more problematic due to the increase of thinner and lighter devices, which limit options for effective cable shielding and antenna isolation. While the data rates increase, the high-frequency data and clocks generate RF noise that falls into Wi-Fi radio bands. Besides RF noise from eDP, timing controller (TCON), used to convert the eDP signal and drive the individual pixels of the display, could be another source of interference.

Software Mitigation Solution Enable Intel Wi-Fi Module Notch Filter

Intel Wi-Fi module supports a notch filter enabling that is configurated through BIOS based on specific request. The notch filter solution aims for narrowband noise mitigation and may impact Wi-Fi performance in some scenarios. Please refer to Intel White Paper #825912 or contact Intel wireless customer support for more information.

Intel Wi-Fi Module Notch Filter Implementation

EMC Component Selection

Common Mode Choke Selection

The common mode choke (CMC) selection is shown below.

Alternatively, PCB CMC can be also considered for eDP 1.4, eDP 1.5, Type-C USB+DP (10 Gbps), USB3.2 Gen 1 and USB3.2 Gen2 signal. Refer to #546122 for Intel PCB Common Mode Choke License Technology Technical White Paper.

InterfaceData RateCMC PlacementCMC Cutoff Frequency (3dB Bandwidth)CMC Insertion LossCM Rejection (10-dB Band)$[internal] Reference Part
eDP 1.48.1 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz<1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
eDP 1.58.1 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector> 10 GHz< 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8 - 3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
HDMI 2.0*6 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>6 GHz<0.35 dB @1.5 GHz, <0.50 dB @3.0 GHz0.3-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
HDMI 2.16 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz<1.0 dB @ 6 GHz0.3-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
Type-C USB+DP10 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz<1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
USB2.0**480 Mb/s<25 mm routing length from connector<0.2 dB @240 MHz0.5-2.0 GHzDLW21SN900SQ2L
USB3.2 Gen 15 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>7.5 GHz<1.5 dB @2.5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2
USB3.2 Gen 210 Gb/s<25 mm routing length from connector>10 GHz<1.2 dB @ 5 GHz1.8-3.8 GHzNFG0QHB372HS2

* To provide longer channel length the insertion loss criteria for HDMI interface is set to low loss value. The EMI/ RF Interference issues caused by HDMI common mode noise are mitigated using CMC and chassis level mitigations such as connector shell grounding etc. ** Common mode chokes with a target common mode impedance of 80 to 90 Ohm at 100 MHz generally provide adequate noise attenuation for USB2.0. Higher impedance CMC generally have a greater damaging effect on signal quality. Signal quality must be checked for low-speed, full-speed and high-speed USB operations in the case of high impedance component is used.

CMC Placement Guideline for USB3 Interface

Port Usage ScenarioCMC Guideline
USB3 onlyPlace Tx CMCs; Rx CMCs are optional
USB3 & DPPlace both Tx and Rx CMCs due to emission from DP
USB3 & TBTDo not place either Tx or Rx CMCs

ESD Diode Selection

ESD diode selection recommendations below only apply to interfaces with:

  • Hotplug input/output port application (external ports that exposed to end user)

  • Direct connection between SOC and connector (Eg, without redriver / retimer in between)

For interfaces that require retimer:

  • Intel retimer: Please refer to Thunderbolt retimer or controller documentation for more details, document number can be found in PDG chapter EMC/RF Reference Documents.

  • Third party retimer: Customer may contact vendor for necessary ESD protection.

For further ESD design optimization, customer may refer to Chapter System Efficient ESD Design (SEED) for more details.

InterfaceData RateESD Diode PlacementESD Diode Shunt CapacitanceESD Diode RdynESD Diode Reverse Working Voltage$[internal]Reference Part
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate 6 Gbps (Data) 6 Gbps< 25 mm routing length from connector< 0.4 pF< 0.5 Ohm3.3 VPESD3V3Z1BSF
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate > 6Gbps(Data)> 6 Gbps< 25 mm routing length from connector< 0.4 pF< 0.5 Ohm3.3 VPESD3V3Z1BSF
HDMI connector HPD/DDC pins< 25 mm routing length from connector5.0 VPESD5V0H1BSF
Type-C USB+DP10 Gbps< 25 mm routing length from connector< 0.35 pF< 0.5 Ohm1.0 VESDL2011,ESDL2012
Type-C connector CC1/CC2 pins< 25 mm routing length from connector5.5 VESD131-B1-W0201
Type-C connector SBU1/SBU2 pins< 25 mm routing length from connector5.5 VESD108-B1-CSP0201
USB2.0480 Mbps< 25 mm routing length from connector< 1.5 pF< 0.8 Ohm5.5 VESD131-B1-W0201
USB3.2 Gen1/2Type A10 Gbps< 25 mm routing length from connector< 0.35 pF< 0.5 Ohm3.3 VPESD3V3Z1BSF

Other Component Selection

Interface/ IO ConnectorComponent RequirementRecommended Details$[internal] Reference Part
Type C Connector ESD Protection (#1)ESD protection for Tx/Rx, CC, SBU linesRefer ESD Diode Selection chapter for more details.
Type C Connector D+/- (#2)ESD and CMC protection for USB 2 data linesRefer ESD diode selection and Common mode choke selection chapter for more details respectively.
Type-C connector CC pins (#3)Decoupling capacitors on CC1 and CC2 pinsRefer to USB PD controller Specification, if not 200 pF is recommended.
Type-C connector Tx/ Rx AC caps (#4)AC caps for Tx, Rx lanesIn order to avoid EOS damage due to shorting between VBUS and adjacent pins, AC cap with voltage rating >= 50 V VBUS maximum voltage rating is required for both Tx and Rx lanes; consider EPR requirement if applicable. The AC cap needs to be next to the connector and followed by ESD diode. Refer to SI PDG for values/placement.
Type-C connector VBUS pinsFerrite bead on VBUS (#5)Optional. Selection based on current rating requirement of the platform.
Type-C connector VBUS pinsDecoupling capacitors on VBUS signal pins (x4) (#6)Refer to Type-C Specifications for more details. (If no specific value is given then it is recommended to use 0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller)
Type-C connector VBUS pinsVBUS ESD Protection (#7)Select the TVS diode as per the VBUS voltage ratings.
AC JACK (#8)Ferrite bead on power and ground pins of AC JACKFerrite bead rated current>=Maximum current rating for the power line. Selection criteria: >80 Ohm Impedance between 100-300 MHzBLM18SG121TN1 (up to 3 A); BLM31SN500SH1 (up to 12 A)
Touch SPI InterfacePlaceholder for shunt capacitorTouch SPI interface nets are single ended nets operating at >=20MHz frequency, so recommended to have shunt capacitor placeholder for clock and IO nets. 27pF (placeholder)
Voltage regulator EMI filter at the voltage regulator input pin (ferrite bead)Optional. Switching Voltage regulators can show broadband noise in the LTE low band, adding ferrite bead can help in reducing the noise. Ferrite bead selection is based on the current rating of the voltage regulator input pin.ILHB1206ER121V (up to 6A); BLM31SN500SH1 (up to 12 A)

Components for Type-C Interface

The image below indicates various components added on the Type C connector for ESD, EMI and EOS protection. For more details about component selection refer Other Component Selection (#1 to #7) table.

Components For Type C Interface

Ferrite Bead for Power and Ground Pins of AC Jack

To prevent EMI noise passing through adapter cable adding ferrite bead at the connector pin can help. For more details refer to AC Jack (#8) details from Other Component Selection table.

Ferrite Beads for AC Jack

PCB CMC

Refer to #546122 for Intel PCB Common Mode Choke License Technology Technical White Paper.

PCB Common Mode Choke Design

System Efficient ESD Design (SEED)

SEED defines an ESD robustness design concept that assures matching between PCB protection components and IC IO behavior during system ESD discharges event. This design concept is applying to hotplug input/output port application, that includes USB2, USB3, Type-C, Display Port, and HDMI.

SEED Block Diagram

Refer to Intel System Efficient ESD Design (SEED) User Guide (CDI# 617148) for step by step simulation using ADS* and Hspice*.

Intel SEED Analysis Template

EMC Audio

Audio ESD

Audio jack needs to have ESD protections. The ESD diodes need to connect the digital/ chassis ground.

Audio Jack ESD Protection

DMIC EMI/ RFI Risk

DMIC clock may have EMI/ RFI risk due to its high-order harmonics.

It is recommended to have stripline routing and a placeholder for an RC filter before being routed in microstrip/ cable to reduce high-frequency harmonics.

The RC value may vary according to the board design to meet the electrical requirements.

RC Filter for DMIC Clock

Wi-Fi/WWAN Radios Performance vs. Platform Noise

Noise from platform components such as high speed traces and clocks can radiate and couple to the antennas of integrated radios such as Wi-Fi or LTE. This is referred to as radio frequency interference and results is degraded signal to noise ratio at the input to the radio receiver. The degraded SNR will impact the data throughput as well as range on the wireless link.

Different noise sources from the platform will have different frequency spectrum. For example, a scrambled signal, such as USB3 will appear with broadband frequency content ranging from DC to 5 GHz. A clock signal, on the other hand will result in single-tone (narrow band) peaks at the harmonic frequencies of the clock frequency.

Platform Threshold Recommendation

Figure A shows measured Wi-Fi throughput as a function of RFI level (broadband and single-tone). Table A shows the noise threshold above which Wi-Fi throughput starts to decrease.

Figure B shows measured SISO reference sensitivity as a function of RFI level (broadband and narrowband noise). The 3GPP specified the SISO reference sensitivity over all LTE bands is -90.3~-93.8 dBm. Table B lists the noise threshold that the measured reference sensitivity starts to fail 3GPP requirement.

It is recommended to ensure that the platform noise coupled to the Wi-Fi/ LTE antennas be lower than this threshold.

Wi-Fi Throughput vs. RFI Level
WWAN Sensitivity vs RFI

On-board Shielding

In the consideration of Wi-Fi/ WWAN/ 5G antenna placement in proximity with PCB board, gaps or slits in between chassis covers allows the noise leak towards antenna. Platform noise may be guided by chassis cover towards antenna. Improved chassis design and on board shielding could isolate platform noise from interfering to the radio devices performances.

Chassis and On-board Shielding Consideration

EMI Shielding Design

An integrated active cooling and EMI shield solution implemented onto Intel LPDDR4 reference platform of Type-3 PCB is shown in the figures below. This demonstrated EMI shield covers the entire core area, including DRAM subsystem, CPU, and power delivery circuits in Type-3 PCB and is an example of the co-design of active thermal and EMI shield solutions. For key implementation principals and PCB design aspects of this shield, please refer to the Intel whitepaper # 621488, "New DRAM Technology and Compelling EMI Shield Mitigation Solutions Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) Analysis"

Reference Platform with EMI Shield Solution
EMI Gasket Surround Shield and Connect to Board Ground Pad Opening

In the using of fabric-over-foam gasket in making connection between shielding lid and frame or between shielding can and PCB, a minimum of 20% or higher compression should be considered in ensuring the electrical effectiveness. Components height and distance from shielding solution depends on heat pipe routing and system thermal & mechanical design. Shielding solution inclusive of compressed gasket should avoid physical collision and interference with components.

Gasket Compression Required for Electrical Effectiveness

EMI shielding could be one of RFI mitigation for exposed power planes and memory devices. Shielding mechanical enclosure should not have electrical openings for minimum noise leakage.

Good Conductivity Between Shielding Lid and Frame

Another example of shielding solution with co-optimized EMC-thermal solution that adopts a large metal frame interposer that cover GPU, GDDR devices, GPU voltage regulator, CPU, DDR devices and voltage regulator. The metal frame has electrical conductive interface connects to on board GND pad opening.

Example Implementation of EMC-Thermal Solution
Metal Frame Interposer with Electrical Conductive Interface to Board

Shielding cans or lids are subject to warpage issues. Shielding design should consider sufficient screws in provide effective mechanical force in the shielding mating or closure. Screw size, count and contact subject to PCB thickness, gasket interface and shielding material. Structure analysis required in ensuring the thermal/ EMI shielding provides appropriate/ uniform pressure on die, and ensuring good gasket stiffness and proper electrical contact of gasket towards PCB GND.

Adequate Mechanical Forces in Shielding Attachment

EMI/ RFI Lidless Shielding Solution

The Lidless shielding solution relies on the case (C or D cover) to be used as the lid of the fence. This design requires the use of a taller fence, electrically conductive gasket and a conductive case or conductive coated case. The conductive case can be achieved using a metallic case or a conductive coatings over a plastic chassis. The figure below shows an example implementation of this shield concept. Note: EMI Lidless shielding implementation shall include system thermal and airflow design consideration.

Example Implementation of Lidless Shielding Solution Concept

Air flow to the enclosure and mechanical strength of the shielding are factors of the shield. Balanced trade off is required for air ventilation hole for thermal conductivity and RF shielding effectiveness. An example of optimized ventilation and effective RF shielding fence is illustrated in figure below.

Trade-off between Air Flow Ventilation and RF Shielding Effectiveness

An opening in the fence allows the heat pipe to go through it, however the heat pipe must be grounded and the space between the fence and heat pipe needs to be sealed. Flexible gasket is a good option to fill the spaces, especially in complex geometries. This gasket helps to avoid rigid unions and geometry irregularities. Refer to the suppliers data sheet to determine the requirements to achieve the electrical conductivity (percentage of compression required).The flexible gasket can be used to seal irregular components such as heat pipes or other complex geometries. When the gasket is compressed, lateral expansion can occur, which should be considered as part of the design. KOZ requirements with respect to electrical components may be needed to avoid short circuits.

Flexible Conductive Gasket for Enclosure

Shielding Ground Contact

Platform on-board shielding can be an effective mitigation options for EMC and help to reduce platform noise radiation and reduce susceptibility to external RF noise. Proper ground contact of the shield is critical to ensuring shielding effectiveness. In consideration of (/10) @ 7.5 GHz, the following figure shows the maximum recommended spacing between grounding pads and vias. Poor grounding contact or gaps/ seams in the shield can reduce the shielding effectiveness.

On Board Shielding Guidelines

EMC Mechanical Consideration

Mechanical design of the system plays a critical role in meeting requirements for EMI, ESD, RFI, RF Immunity and EFT. The broad categories of consideration in mechanical design are chassis design, connector selection and grounding, high speed cable design and grounding. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 "Chassis Design Guidelines for Improving RF Immunity and Electromagnetic Compatibility" for detailed design guidelines.

Chassis Design Considerations

It is recommended to have conductive coating used for chassis covers (in case of plastic chassis) and coating should also cover the chassis sidewalls. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for guidelines on the coating thickness and selection criteria.

EMI Coating on Non Metallic Chassis

Conductive contacts along the mating interface between two covers of the chassis are required to reduce the size of the openings between chassis covers. Left figure below shows the chassis contact impact between the C and D faces of the chassis. Mounting holes for screws that are used to secure the motherboard to the chassis or between chassis faces should not have non-conductive coating and the PCB solder mask exposed for the screw to make contact to the PCB ground. The metal back-plate of the LCD screen and back-plate of the keyboard should not be left as a floating metal, and they should be properly grounded. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for further guidance on the contact between chassis faces.

Conductive Contacts for Chassis Faces and PCB Ground

The metal shell of IO connectors, such as USB3, HDMI etc. should make contact to the chassis either using EMI gaskets of metal fingers in the chassis. Figure in right shows a block diagram of gasket making connection between IO connector and chassis. For the commonly used fabric-over-foam gaskets to be effective, a minimum of 20% or higher compression is required.

Gasket with Compression to Connect IO Connector and Chassis

The receptacle connector should have good area of contact to the printed circuit board. Figure below shows an example of metal fingers in chassis for IO connector contacts.

Metal Fingers in Chassis for IO Connector Contact

The thermal solution (heat pipe, cold plate) should be grounded to eliminate/reduce any resonance effects that could amplify noise in vicinity. EMI gasket material can be applied to ground the thermal solution at multiple locations (either to PCB ground or chassis ground). Grounding near the fins is also recommended. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for further guidance on the thermal solution grounding.

Thermal Solution Grounding

Internal Cable/Connector Routing and Shielding

Cable Routing

In a typical laptop system, several internal cables are used to connect to components such as speakers, displays, daughter cards etc. The routing of the internal cables is critical to reduce the amount of noise coupling to the sensitive circuits or nearby radio antennas, especially for the cables without good shielding. Routing cables close to the aggressor like DDR, HSIO, and SSD, could result in critical radio frequency interference (RFI) and EMI (regulatory) issues. For further guidelines on cable routing, refer to Intel White Paper #602554.

Cable and connector shielding

  • A shielded micro-coax cable assembly or 3-layer FPC cable are recommended for high-speed signals.

  • The method by which the shield layers of a cable are well contacted to ground has a significant impact on mitigating the noise radiation. A floating shield layer does not provide a return current path and may even make the noise radiation worse.

  • The shield layer(s) of the cable should make contact to the plug shell (ground) of the cable.

  • In addition, the receptacle of the cable should have ground contact to the PCB ground at multiple locations or to the chassis through the gasket.

Grounding Scheme for Internal Cable and Connector
Examples of ground contacts on the receptacle of the cable and connector

Type-C Receptacle Connector Selection

Following are the recommendations for USB Type C, A receptacle connector selection.

Connector Selection and RFI Mitigation
Avoid Holes and Slits in Type-C Receptacle Connector

EMC ESD Considerations

ESD Sensitive Net Mitigation

The following net categories may be sensitive to ESD:

  • Processor-Hot or PCH-Hot: *PROCHOT* / *PCHHOT*

  • Reset: *RESET* / *RST* / *RSTB*/*DRAM_RESET*

  • Power-Ok, Power-Good: *PWROK* / *PWRGD*

  • XTAL_IN & XTAL_OUT

System-level ESD issues may be mitigated by one of the following:

  • Routing sensitive nets as stripline.

  • Adding placeholder for decoupling capacitors on the sensitive nets to reduce the ESD level injected into the victim ICs (excluding crystal oscillator). The value of decoupling capacitor varies on different nets and systems. The recommended value is 1-100 nF.

For crystal oscillator, follow the guidelines from XTAL Topology Guideline (PCH/IOs chapter) and XTAL Ground Ring Requirement (Electromagnetic Compatibility Chapter).

ESD Sensitive Net Mitigation

EMC/ RF Reference Documents

PDG Sub-section(s)Document NumberDocument Name

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_IO on Layer 1 and Layer 6, with solid ground reference layers on Layer 2 and Layer 5VCCPRIM_IO_1
2VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR should be merged with VCCPRIM_IO through an LC filter on the secondary side on Layer 6VCCPRIM_IO_1
3VCCPRIM_IO VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power sense line is connected to SENSE_VCCPRIM_IO BGA(BM80), and the ground sense line is connected to VSS pth closest to the SENSE_VCCPRIM_IO pth , VSS pth recommended to be within 4.5mm distance of the power sense pth. VCCPRIM_IO_2
4Max resistance and loop inductance recommended for VCCPRIM_IO from VR to BGA are 11 mOhm and 2nH. Refer to the "Inductance Calculation Method" in technical advisory 642578 for setup to extract inductance.VCCPRIM_IO_3
VCCPRIM_IO_1
VCCPRIM_IO_2
VCCPRIM_IO_3
Notes
Note
Pair board caps with power/ground vias. Align caps along current flow path from VR to BGA
Use components with 6.3V voltage rating.
Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package . For example, Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->VR
Component PlacementForm FactorValueSoldered DownISC SocketPPV SocketNoteReference Design
Secondary side (inductor)06031 uH/110mOhm111Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR railVCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side040210 uF111Decoupling capacitor placed on VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR rail for LC filtering purposeVCCPRIM_IO_4
VCCPRIM_IO_4

VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA (Internal Use Only)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1High level block diagram to show connectivity for VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA with two VR options: 1. Shared VR with VCCPRIM_VNNAON 2. Dedicated motherboard LVR (placeholder/backup option)VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA_Block_Diagram
2Recommendation to route VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA on secondary layer & motherboard LVR component placement as shown in the image VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA_Layout
3Resistor stuffing option- Stuff resistor1 (unstuff resistor2) when it comes from VCCPRM_VNNAON VR & stuff resistor 2 (unstuff resistor1) when it comes from dedicated motherboard LVRVCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA_Layout
4For POR kindly refer VCCPRIM_VNNAON section in PDG
VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA_Block_Diagram
VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA_Layout

Note
smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package . For example, Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->VR

Use components with 6.3V voltage rating.

secondary side 040210uF2Place capacitor under UCIe BGAs.vccprim_ucie_ana

VCCPRIM_VNNAON

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane on Layer 1,3, 4 and 6 with solid GND reference on layer 2 and 5.Vccprim_vnnaon_LAYOUT1
2Block diagram shows the connectivity where VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA, VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR and VCCST are connected to VCCPRIM_VNNAON through shorting resistor, LC filter and Power Gate respectively. Block Diagram
3Recommendation is to isolate VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR, VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA from VCCPRIM_VNNAON as shown in image. Refer to reference design image as guidance for design implementation.VRM is 28mm and VCCRPIM_UCIE_ANA BGAs is 14mm away from shorting resistor. This shorting resistor is defined as split point. Inductor is placed between VCCPRIM_VNNAON and VCCPRIM_VNNAON FLTR rail near the split point and is 30mm away from VRM.Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT2
4The loop inductance recommended from VRM to farthest VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA should be less than 1nH and Rdc value should be less than 5mohm.Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT3
5VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power sense line is connected to VCCPRIM_VNNAON pth, and the ground sense line is connected to VSS pth closest to the VCCPRIM_VNNAON pth.Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT4
6Sense is placed as shown in image closer to the inductor. Sense is 9mm away from VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs . Rpath recommended from VRM to sense location should be less than 5mohm.Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT4
Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT1
Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT2
Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT3
Vccprim_vnnaon__LAYOUT4
Block Diagram
Notes
Note
Pair board caps with power/ground vias. Align caps along current flow path from VR to BGA.
Use components with 6.3V voltage rating.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side 7343Placeholder1Place bulk capacitor on VCCPRIM_VNNAON rail close to VRM VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
Secondary Side060322 uF6Place capacitor C1-C6 as shown in image at distance 18mm from VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAsVCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
Secondary side060322 uF3Place capacitor C7,C8 & C9 on VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA rail as shown in image at distance 12mm from VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA BGAsVCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
Secondary side060322 uF1Place C11 under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
Secondary side040210 uF2Place capacitor C12 & C13 under VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA BGAs.(BL73,BJ75,BJ71) VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
Secondary side08051 uH / 0.055 Ohm DCR1Use a 1 uH inductor with max DCR of 0.055 Ohm to connect VCCPRIM_VNNAON and VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FTLR for an LC filter scheme.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
Secondary side060322 uF1Decoupling C10 is placed on VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR rail for LC filtering purpose under VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs(BP54,BP51)VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane on Layer 1,3, 4 and 6 with solid GND reference on layer 2 and 5.Vccprim_vnnaon_LAYOUT1
2Block diagram shows the connectivity where VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA, VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR and VCCST are connected to VCCPRIM_VNNAON through shorting resistor, LC filter and Power Gate respectively. Block Diagram
3Recommendation is to isolate VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR, VCCPRIM_UCIE_ANA from VCCPRIM_VNNAON as shown in image. Refer to reference design image as guidance for design implementation.VRM is 28mm and VCCRPIM_UCIE_ANA BGAs is 14mm away from shorting resistor. This shorting resistor is defined as split point. Inductor is placed between VCCPRIM_VNNAON and VCCPRIM_VNNAON FLTR rail near the split point and is 30mm away from VRM.Vccprim_vnnaon_LAYOUT2
4The loop inductance recommended from VRM to farthest VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA should be less than 1nH and Rdc value should be less than 5mohm.Vccprim_vnnaon_LAYOUT3
5VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power sense line is connected to VCCPRIM_VNNAON pth, and the ground sense line is connected to VSS pth closest to the VCCPRIM_VNNAON pth.Vccprim_vnnaon_LAYOUT4
6Sense is placed as shown in image closer to the inductor. Sense is 9mm away from VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs . Rpath recommended from VRM to sense location should be less than 5mohm.Vccprim_vnnaon_LAYOUT4

VCC_PCORE

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_1e
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
4Populate minimum 18 PTHs under the BGA to achieve optimum performance, see diagram for recommended locations.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_4e
T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_1e
T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_4e
Notes
Note
1. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
2. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side7343330 uF1Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5 mOhmT3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_2e
Primary side7343Placeholder1 T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_2e
Secondary side02011 uF6Place directly under BGA.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_3e
Secondary side040210 uF8Place directly under BGA.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_3e
Secondary side0402Placeholder2These placeholders can be placed near to package edge wherever there are spaces.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_3e
Secondary side060322 uF4Place at least 1x0603 cap under BGA, the rest place close to the package egde.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_3e
Secondary side0603Placeholder5These placeholders can be placed near to package edge wherever there are spaces.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_3e
T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_2e
T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_3e

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_1i
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
4Add a parallel plane on a validation layer to compesate DCR loss due to ISC/PPV socket. Please see reference image for the plane routing requirement.T3_PCB_VCC_PCORE_4i

VCCSA

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement.T3_PCB_VCCSA_1e
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.

4Populate minimum 16 PTHs under the BGA to achieve optimum performance, see diagram for recommended locations.T3_PCB_VCCSA_4e
5The VCCSA rail required to meet the R-path = 4.7mOhm at the furthest end of Layer3, as shown. This can be achieved with the core routing as recommended.T3_PCB_VCCSA_5e

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. T3_PCB_VCC_LP_ECORE_1i
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
4Add a parallel plane on a validation layer to compesate DCR loss due to ISC/PPV socket. Please see reference image for the plane routing requirement.T3_PCB_VCC_LP_ECORE_4i
T3_PCB_VCC_LP_ECORE_1i
T3_PCB_VCC_LP_ECORE_4i
Notes
Note
Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.

VDDQ_T3_LP5_2

DDR5 Device Decoupling

Small Outline Dual In-line Memory Module (SODIMM)

DDR5 SODIMM comes with PMIC/ VR and decoupling on the module card itself, hence no additional decoupling guidelines are required. Nevertheless the source supply to the DDR5 SODIMM needs to follow the JEDEC/ vendor specification sheet.

DDR5 SODIMM comes with PMIC/ VR and decoupling on the module card itself, hence no additional decoupling guidelines are required. Nevertheless the source supply to the DDR5 SODIMM needs to follow the JEDEC/ vendor specification sheet.

LPDDR5/x Device Decoupling

Memory Down Decoupling Config: 2X32

Description: LPDDR5x x32 memory down PI solution guidance with eDVFSC enabled on the platform.

eDVFSC is an optional power savings feature for LP5x speed 3200 MT/s. eDVFSC requires an independent VDD2L rail on the platform. If the eDVFSC support is not desired on the platform, customers can merge DRAM VDD2L ball with the VDD2H rail. Customers should consult the DRAM vendors for Z(f) spec guidance for merged VDD2H/VDD2L rail.

Notes
Note
TYPE-3 6L DRAM power rail layer assignment is provided in LPDDR5x_TYPE3_1
VSS referencing is recommended for all the Memory power rails
Information provided here is only for guidance. Customers are responsible for meeting all JEDEC SPECS on the Memory power rails
Voltage RailCapacitor Form Factor and ValueQuantityNotesReference Design
VDD2H0201, 1 uF84 caps per DRAM, 1 per side close to VDD2H BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
VDD2H0402, 10 uF21 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
VDDQ0201, 1 uF84 caps per DRAM, 1 per each corner close to VDDQ BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
VDDQ0402, 10 uF21 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
VDD10201, 1 uF84 caps per DRAM, 1 per each VDD1 BGA. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
VDD10402, 10 uF42 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
VDD2L0201, 1uF84 cap per DRAM, 1 per each corner close to VDD2L BGA's Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5
VDD2L0402, 10uF21 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_1
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5

RCOMP

RCOMP Connection Diagram
Example_RCOMP_with_GND_shield
RCOMP General Guidelines
Detail
Trace width 88um with min trace spacing 100um.
Max total length on board = 9 mm. Max number of vias 1.
GND shield to any high speed IO with VSS trace/ strip. This is not required if the adjacent signal is another RCOMP signal. PTH vias are required to be punched from this GND shield to the referenced GND plane.
GND reference required. Noisy or switching references should be avoided.
Board external resistor size=0201(recommended).
Strongly recommended to follow breakout board placement.
RCOMP Configuration
InterfaceSignal NameBoard RTerm (Ohm)Max Board DC resistance (Ohm)Tolerance (+/-)%Connection on other SideMax Board Parasitic Capacitance (pF)Resistor StuffingRouting Guide
ClockCLK_S_RCOMP1800.11GND1.5Mandatorya) If 178 Ohm +/- 1% tolerance is also acceptable. b) Unused RCOMP can be left as not connected. refer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
